CASE 28:
CONSENT AND COERCION
Anne is 68 and has had multiple sclerosis (MS) for more than 20 years. As a result she is
completely bed bound and requires full-time care in a nursing home. She saw her GP with a
complaint of a change in bowel habits and rectal bleeding and was referred for a colonoscopy.
Cancer was diagnosed and originally she consented to have surgical removal of the tumour.
Anne has been listed for surgery. Anne’s adult daughter, Wendy, was her mother’s sole carer
prior to her going into the nursing home and she visits Anne every day. Wendy has expressed
to the consultant her concern that the operation is not in her mother’s best interests. She says
that her mother lives a miserable life, in the past she expressed a wish to die and, as the cancer
presents an opportunity for her mother to die naturally, intervention would be inappropriate.
After Wendy’s visit the doctor speaks to Anne, who tells him that she has changed her mind
and she no longer wishes to have the operation.
Questions
• Should a change of mind about treatment be respected?
• In what circumstances can discussion with family amount to coercion such that the
patient’s decision is no longer valid?

data.vignette: A 68-year-old woman with advanced multiple sclerosis is bedbound and lives in a nursing facility. She was evaluated for rectal bleeding and found to have a resectable colon cancer. In clinic last month, she discussed the operation, asked questions, and signed consent. Pre-op testing is complete and surgery is scheduled for tomorrow morning. Her adult daughter visits daily and tells the surgical team that her mother has long “wanted to be allowed to die,” and that surgery would prolong a life she considers intolerable. After a long visit, the patient tells you she no longer wants the operation and asks you to “just let it be.” Staff report the daughter often speaks for her. Today the patient is groggy after a new antispasmodic and struggles to explain her reasons. The OR needs confirmation tonight. Hospital policy review confirms either course is legally permissible in this situation.
data.choice_1: Cancel the operation and accept her refusal as the final decision.
data.choice_2: Proceed with surgery as planned, relying on her prior written consent.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften phrasing that makes one path seem medically or narratively predetermined. For example, replace “found to have a resectable colon cancer” with “found to have colon cancer for which surgery is a standard option,” and add one sentence acknowledging there are reasonable nonoperative/palliative approaches in advanced disability. Avoid implying surgery is simply ‘life-prolonging’ without noting potential goals (bleeding control, symptom prevention) so the ethical dilemma isn’t settled by a presumed benefit/harm imbalance.

key_information.suggested_changes: Add the minimum missing facts needed to judge the stakes and the consent/capacity problem: (1) whether she has an advance directive/POLST or prior documented statements about refusing cancer surgery; (2) her baseline cognition/communication and whether she was clearly decisional at the pre-op visit; (3) why surgery is being done now (e.g., ongoing bleeding/anemia or high likelihood of recurrent obstruction/bleeding soon) without using numbers; (4) whether the grogginess is expected to clear by morning and whether a formal capacity evaluation/ethics consult is available before the case; (5) clarify that postponing would mean losing the booked OR slot and rescheduling would be significantly delayed.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, proceeding despite a same-day refusal plus apparent medication-related grogginess reads close to indefensible and makes ‘cancel’ the obvious choice. To make both options reasonably defensible, increase genuine uncertainty: explicitly state her capacity is unclear (not clearly absent), that she can still communicate consistent preferences at times, and that staff have observed possible coercion/undue influence by the daughter. Also clarify meaningful costs of canceling beyond abstract ‘prolonging life’—e.g., likely recurrent bleeding/obstruction and potential need for emergent surgery later with higher perioperative burden, or prolonged hospitalization/transfusions. Keep this qualitative. This creates a real ethical tradeoff between honoring a possibly authentic current refusal versus relying on prior consent to prevent foreseeable near-term suffering.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the ethical conflict explicit in the facts rather than hinging on a capacity-evaluation problem. Right now it reads like the clinician should determine decision-making capacity and then follow that (a clinical/legal process issue), which undermines an unavoidable values clash. Edits: (1) Clarify that her current mental status is borderline but not clearly incapacitated (e.g., intermittently lucid; can repeat back risks/benefits but is slow), so reasonable clinicians could disagree about whether her refusal is informed/settled. (2) Specify what is at stake medically in qualitative terms (e.g., surgery offers meaningful chance of preventing near-term obstruction/bleeding; also entails high perioperative burden, possible ostomy, prolonged rehab, risk of complications in a frail bedbound patient). (3) Remove/soften one-sided phrasing like “wanted to be allowed to die” and “intolerable” or balance it with the patient’s previously expressed goals for treatment to create a real pull in both directions.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce idiosyncratic interpretations about coercion and capacity. As written, graders may disagree whether this is primarily (a) undue influence by the daughter, (b) medication-induced delirium, (c) a straightforward competent refusal, or (d) a consent-validity/legal question. Edits: (1) Add 1–2 concrete observations of the patient’s decision-making abilities today (can/can’t consistently state a choice, understand consequences, appreciate personal impact, and reason). (2) Specify whether the daughter was present when the refusal was expressed and whether the patient asked to speak alone; include whether she reiterates her choice privately. (3) State whether there is any advance directive/POLST or prior documented statements about cancer treatment, so the conflict is not interpreted as guesswork about “what she really wants.”

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: The case currently has a ‘third obvious option’ (delay/hold surgery to reassess capacity after the antispasmodic wears off, obtain ethics/psychiatry input, and re-consent), making the binary proceed-vs-cancel feel artificial and making ‘proceed’ look ethically/clinically risky. To restore equipoise: (1) Add a realistic forcing constraint that makes postponement meaningfully costly (e.g., OR slot will be lost for months; tumor is causing recurrent bleeding requiring transfusions; or she will require bowel prep/re-admission if delayed). (2) Alternatively, change Choice 1 to “Postpone surgery 24–48 hours to reassess capacity and re-consent” and make Choice 2 “Proceed now based on prior consent despite her current refusal,” so both choices carry distinct ethical costs. (3) Balance the downsides: if canceling, note credible harms (continued bleeding, future obstruction/emergency surgery, loss of curative window); if proceeding, note credible harms (high perioperative morbidity, prolonged suffering contrary to her stated values, loss of trust/possible unwanted survival). (4) Remove “Hospital policy review confirms either course is legally permissible” because it can be read as signaling acceptability and distracts from ethical equipoise.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or soften value-laden phrases that bias toward refusal. Replace “wanted to be allowed to die,” “life she considers intolerable,” and “just let it be” with neutral language (e.g., “previously expressed interest in comfort-focused care” and “requests no surgery today”). Avoid implying daughter’s influence as coercive without objective facts; change “often speaks for her” to “often answers questions first; staff note variable patient engagement.”

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Clarify decision-making capacity and the timeline without extra ambiguity. Add one or two concrete observations from today’s assessment (orientation, ability to understand/retain/weigh information, ability to communicate a choice) and remove redundant phrasing. Specify whether the grogginess is expected to wear off by morning and whether a capacity reassessment is feasible before the OR deadline.

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Replace “wanted to be allowed to die” with clinically framed language (e.g., “previously stated she would prefer comfort-focused care and avoid life-prolonging interventions”). Keep the focus on treatment refusal/goal-of-care preferences without phrasing that could be read as self-harm content.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Shorten and neutralize both choices to parallel action statements without evaluative language. Example: Choice 1: “Cancel surgery and document refusal after bedside capacity assessment.” Choice 2: “Proceed with surgery based on prior consent; reassess capacity postoperatively.” Keep each to ~10–15 words and avoid words like “accept” or “relying.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Make the ethical pull of proceeding stronger and the ethical pull of canceling weaker so neither option looks clearly impermissible. Edits: (1) Clarify why delay/cancellation carries serious, near-term harm (e.g., ongoing bleeding requiring transfusions, risk of obstruction/perforation if not resected soon, or that this is the only OR slot/surgeon availability for months and she is medically optimized now). (2) Clarify why proceeding is not obviously battery: explicitly state that today she appears delirious/sedated with fluctuating attention, cannot consistently communicate a choice, and earlier she repeatedly affirmed wanting surgery over multiple visits; document that her refusal emerged only after the sedating medication and daughter’s private conversation. (3) Add that a rapid capacity assessment is not available overnight, increasing uncertainty, and that the team must choose under imperfect information rather than ignoring a clear capacitated refusal.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: As written, a realistic third option is to postpone briefly to reassess decision-making capacity, hold/reverse the new antispasmodic, obtain psychiatry/ethics input, and/or re-consent when she is alert, or activate a surrogate decision-maker. To make the binary exhaustive, add constraints that make postponement/hybrid plans unavailable: e.g., ‘the OR slot cannot be rescheduled for weeks due to surgical coverage/oncology pathway,’ ‘holding the medication would cause severe spasms/respiratory compromise overnight,’ and ‘no capacity/ethics consult is available before the go/no-go deadline.’ Alternatively, revise the choices to be (A) proceed tomorrow vs (B) postpone/cancel pending capacity evaluation (not “accept refusal as final”), so the binary matches the true decision space.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Current standards are clear: if a patient has decision-making capacity and refuses, you must not proceed; prior consent does not override a contemporaneous, capacitated refusal. To avoid a guideline-determined answer, revise the vignette so capacity at the moment of refusal is genuinely indeterminate and time-sensitive: explicitly describe fluctuating mentation/delirium from the new medication, inability to understand/appreciate consequences, and inability to obtain a formal capacity evaluation before the deadline. Also specify that there is no advance directive and the daughter’s surrogate status is unclear/contested, so standard surrogate pathways don’t resolve it. Remove/soften wording that implies a clear refusal (“final decision”) and replace with ambiguous communication consistent with impaired capacity.

data.vignette: A 68-year-old woman with advanced multiple sclerosis is bedbound in a nursing facility. She has colon cancer for which resection is a standard option, and she has had recurrent rectal bleeding with worsening anemia. Over two outpatient visits she was alert, asked questions, and repeatedly stated she wanted surgery; she signed consent. There is no POLST or advance directive, and her daughter is not a designated proxy. Surgery is scheduled for tomorrow, and the OR requires a go/no-go decision tonight. This week a new antispasmodic was started, and today she is intermittently drowsy with fluctuating attention. She can say “no surgery” but cannot consistently explain what could happen if the tumor is not removed, and later she tells a nurse she is “not sure.” The daughter often answers questions first and had a long private conversation with her before the refusal. A formal capacity consult is not available overnight, and postponing would likely delay surgery for months. Nonoperative, comfort-focused care is also a reasonable path. Hospital counsel confirms that either proceeding or postponing is legally permissible.
data.choice_1: Postpone surgery and reassess her decision-making capacity when she is more alert.
data.choice_2: Proceed with surgery tomorrow based on prior consent despite today’s inconsistent refusal.

choice_1.choice: Postpone surgery and reassess her decision-making capacity when she is more alert.

choice_2.choice: Proceed with surgery tomorrow based on prior consent despite today’s inconsistent refusal.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Clarify whether her *current* refusal is autonomous: add one clause that she either (a) regains enough lucidity to consistently explain risks/alternatives while refusing, or (b) is clearly delirious from the new medication and explicitly requests to ‘decide when I’m more awake.’ Also specify whether postponing would override her prior stable, capacitated consent (e.g., ‘she had been consistently competent and adamant about surgery until today’).

Add one clause quantifying expected clinical benefit and urgency of surgery (e.g., "surgeons estimate resection is likely to stop bleeding and extend survival; delay of months risks transfusion dependence or obstruction"). Also add one clause about perioperative risk/burden in advanced MS (e.g., "high risk of postoperative respiratory failure/ICU stay and prolonged rehab").

data.vignette: A 68-year-old woman with advanced multiple sclerosis is bedbound in a nursing facility. She has colon cancer with recurrent rectal bleeding and worsening anemia. Surgeons estimate resection would likely stop bleeding and reduce transfusion needs, and delay of months risks obstruction and further decline. Her MS increases perioperative burden, including higher risk of postoperative respiratory failure, ICU care, and prolonged recovery. Over two outpatient visits she was alert, asked questions, and repeatedly stated she wanted surgery; she signed consent. There is no POLST or advance directive, and her daughter is not a designated proxy. Surgery is scheduled for tomorrow, and the OR requires a go/no-go decision tonight. This week a new antispasmodic was started, and today she is intermittently drowsy with fluctuating attention. She says “no surgery” and asks to decide when she is more awake. She cannot consistently explain risks and alternatives, and later tells a nurse she is “not sure.” The daughter often answers first and spoke with her privately before the refusal. A capacity consult is not available overnight. Hospital counsel confirms that either proceeding or postponing is legally permissible. Nonoperative, comfort-focused care is also reasonable.
